awd_titl_txt: EAGER:   SSDIM:   Generating Synthetic Data on Interdependent Food, Energy, and Transportation Networks via Stochastic, Bi-level Optimization
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will generate data at the interdependencies of the energy, food, and transportation infrastructures, providing essential information for contributing to improved approaches to addressing design and operational issues for interdependent critical infrastructures (ICIs). The project introduces a new mathematical framework and applies it to data generation, allowing explicit representation of infrastructure interdependencies. It allows integration of current data generation techniques into a unified representation of societal, mechanistic, and physical aspects of ICIs. All data generated from this research will be made freely available through online repositories. Along with academic publications and presentations, the project will create communication materials such as digital maps for dissemination to practitioners, particularly within rural communities. The findings and outcomes from this research may serve to raise public awareness about infrastructure threats and resilience. This project will also develop a food/energy module for elementary schoolchildren, as well as support for graduate student researchers.

This project will develop a new mathematical framework (Stochastic Bilevel Optimization) to generate synthetic data on ICIs. The project will also provide uncertainty measures associated with these data, allowing a measure of quality as well as quantifying relationships with input information. This method will generate data for interdependent agriculture, food, energy, and transportation ICIs, allowing for integration of existing data generation techniques. The mathematical structure of the stochastic bilevel optimization problem allows for representation of, and integration across, the physical, mechanistic, and community functions of ICIs. The aim is to generate data to optimize strategies for disaster preparedness, resilience, and response.  This research will contribute to the emerging area of food system resilience and will enable future efforts to model potential threats to food systems such as energy supply disruptions and fuel price spikes.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Interdependent critical infrastructures (ICIs), such as food, energy, and transportation, form the backbone of society, driving and sustaining the economy, national security, and well-being. Traditional research studies these different infrastructures in isolation, whereas they are interconnected and interdependent to deliver services that meet societal needs. For example, we need energy not only to produce our food, but also to cook and eat it. We need different types of transportation to move various food and energy products. This transportation is powered by energy from sources that are occasionally dependent on our food system, such as corn-based ethanol.  To meet societal goals for resilience, we need to research the interdependencies of these infrastructures, focusing on how their function is integrated across physical, economic, social, and geographical spheres. One of the major ways to promote research at the interdependencies is by providing data, especially when the data does not exist or is difficult to collect. Further, we need to ensure data is usable by communities, through city governments and local practitioners, to assist them in meeting their goals for resilience.

This project used a new mathematical framework, referred to as bilevel optimization, to generate data at the interdependencies of food, energy, and transportation systems. Examples of these datasets included transport of natural gas across different state pipelines under different possible futures; changes in state-level prices, consumption, and transportation of food products under an outbreak of a food-borne illness; and state-level production of corn under different demands for food and energy. Other examples of interdependencies included data on petroleum use in pesticide production, electricity production through anaerobic digestion, and energy use in food production. The results of this research were published in peer-reviewed journals and presented at conferences. These datasets were made publicly available at the Design Safe cyberinfrastructure, an online platform of the Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure:

https://www.designsafe-ci.org/data/browser/public/designsafe.storage.published/PRJ-2511v2

We incorporated the interdependent infrastructures concepts informed by our research into the development of a practical guide for municipal governments: Food System Resilience: A Planning Guide for Local Governments (2022). https://clf.jhsph.edu/projects/food-system-resilience/resilience-planning-guide. This guide contributes to the Department of Homeland Security's focus on enhancing the security and resilience of end-user communities around the nation.  To develop the guide, we partnered with the Johns Hopkins Centers for Civic Impact (former Center for Government Excellence) and the Food Policy Networks program to convene a Community of Practice (CoP) with representatives from five U.S. city governments. We co-created resources to help end-user communities generate data-driven food system strategies with a strong focus on equity. The CoP consisted of six virtual, interactive discussions on building food system resilience as well as two half-day virtual workshops. Informal group conversations have continued, as well as periodic meetings between city partners and the research team about their next steps in applying and implementing elements of the planning guide. We have two manuscripts in progress describing our process and lessons learned, and an evaluation of the guide is underway.

We communicated about the guide and its concepts through information and training sessions at several well-attended events for food system stakeholders, webinars, social media, and direct outreach to governments, organizations and businesses. Dissemination is ongoing.

The project also funded research and professional development for undergraduate, masters, and PhD students. We developed and taught a graduate course on food system resilience in Spring 2021 and 2022. As part of the course, students piloted selected planning activities from the guidebook, and used related data as the course's final project. We have given multiple guest lectures on food system resilience topics. Co-PI Neff participated as a co-instructor in an open-access Coursera course on food system sustainability issues, including providing a food system resilience lecture. The course has 5,124 total learners and 881 completers.

 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 02/15/2023
Modified by: Karen L Knee
